standards: 4.1.1 Reading and writing numbers up to 100,000 in numerals and words
objectives: Pupils are able to read and write numbers up to 100,000 in numerals and words correctly.
activities: Singing number songs up to 100,000
Writing numbers from words to numerals (example: 'forty-five thousand three hundred' → 45,300)
'Find the Number' game – finding numbers on a large chart
assessment: Worksheets for writing numbers from words
aids: Number word cards (thousands, hundreds, tens, ones)

standards: 4.1.2 Comparing and arranging numbers up to 100,000
objectives: Pupils are able to compare two numbers up to 100,000 and arrange them in ascending or descending order.
activities: Arranging number cards in order
'Largest Number' game – comparing numbers in groups
Using base-ten blocks to show place value
assessment: Worksheets for arranging numbers in ascending/descending order
aids: Base-ten blocks (ten thousands, thousands, hundreds, tens, ones)

standards: 4.2.1 Adding two numbers up to 100,000 without regrouping
objectives: Pupils are able to solve addition mathematical sentences up to 100,000 without regrouping using algorithms or concrete objects.
activities: Using an abacus for addition without regrouping
Writing mathematical sentences on the whiteboard
'Fast Addition' game in pairs

standards: 4.2.2 Adding two numbers up to 100,000 with regrouping
objectives: Pupils are able to solve addition mathematical sentences up to 100,000 with regrouping using algorithms or base-ten blocks.
activities: Using base-ten blocks to show the regrouping process
'Break the Hundreds/Thousands/Ten Thousands' activity – turning 10 hundreds into 1 thousand
Solving daily problems: 'A company has 45,678 books, buys 28,934 more'

standards: 4.3.1 Subtracting two numbers up to 100,000 without regrouping
objectives: Pupils are able to solve subtraction mathematical sentences up to 100,000 without regrouping using algorithms or concrete objects.
activities: Using an abacus for subtraction without regrouping
Writing mathematical sentences on cards
'Take & Calculate' game – taking objects and calculating the balance

standards: 4.3.2 Subtracting two numbers up to 100,000 with regrouping
objectives: Pupils are able to solve subtraction mathematical sentences up to 100,000 with regrouping using algorithms or base-ten blocks.
activities: Using base-ten blocks to show the borrowing process
'Borrow One' activity – changing 1 ten thousand to 10 thousands
Solving daily problems: 'Mother has 80,000 beans, uses 34,567'

standards: 4.4.1 Solving multiplication of two numbers (two-digit number × two-digit number) without regrouping
objectives: Pupils are able to solve multiplication of two digits by two digits without regrouping using algorithms or grids.
activities: Using a multiplication grid (box method)
Writing mathematical sentences on the board
'Product Matching' game

standards: 4.4.2 Solving multiplication of two numbers (two-digit number × two-digit number) with regrouping
objectives: Pupils are able to solve multiplication of two digits by two digits with regrouping using algorithms or base-ten blocks.
activities: Using base-ten blocks to show the regrouping process
'Multiplication Regrouping' activity – turning 10 ones into 1 ten
Solving daily problems: 'Each bag has 24 marbles, 35 bags = ?'

standards: 4.5.1 Solving division of two numbers (three-digit number ÷ two-digit number) without remainder
objectives: Pupils are able to solve division of three digits by two digits without a remainder using algorithms or equal sharing models.
activities: Dividing marbles into containers equally
Using picture cards to show division
'Equal Sharing' game with toy objects

standards: 4.5.2 Solving division of two numbers (three-digit number ÷ two-digit number) with remainder
objectives: Pupils are able to solve division of three digits by two digits with a remainder using algorithms or visual models.
activities: Using base-ten blocks to show the remainder
Short drama: 'I have 125 candies, share with 15 friends, what is the remainder?'
Solving daily problems: '180 books divided among 25 people'

standards: 4.6.1 Understanding and writing equivalent fractions for proper fractions
objectives: Pupils are able to write equivalent fractions for simple proper fractions (example: ½ = ²⁄₄ = ³⁄₆) using visual models or multiplication/division methods.
activities: Using paper circles to show equivalent fractions
Matching equivalent fraction cards
'Find the Equivalent Partner' game in groups
assessment: Oral assessment: 'What is equivalent to ⅔?'
aids: Paper circles for cutting and comparing

standards: 4.6.2 Adding and subtracting proper fractions with the same denominator
objectives: Pupils are able to add and subtract proper fractions with the same denominator using models or algorithms.
activities: Using fraction cards to show addition/subtraction
Drawing circles and coloring parts for addition/subtraction
Solving daily problems: 'I ate ¼ of a pizza, my brother ate ²⁄₄, what is the total?'

standards: 4.7.1 Adding decimals up to three decimal places
objectives: Pupils are able to add decimals up to three decimal places (example: 3.456 + 2.789) using algorithms or visual models.
activities: Using decimal grids for addition
Writing mathematical sentences on the board
'Decimal Addition' game in pairs

standards: 4.7.2 Subtracting decimals up to three decimal places
objectives: Pupils are able to subtract decimals up to three decimal places (example: 5.678 – 2.345) using algorithms or base-ten blocks.
activities: Using base-ten blocks to show the borrowing process
'Borrow One' activity – changing 1 unit to 10 tenths
Solving daily problems: '3.500 L of water, used 1.250 L, what is the balance?'

standards: 4.8.1 Understanding the meaning of percentage (%) and converting percentage to fractions of 100
objectives: Pupils are able to state percentages as fractions of 100 (example: 25% = ²⁵⁄₁₀₀) and vice versa.
activities: Using a 10x10 grid to show percentage
Coloring 30 squares to show 30%
'Find the Percentage' game – matching percentages with fractions
assessment: Oral Q&A: 'What is 50% as a fraction?'

standards: 4.8.2 Converting percentage to decimals and vice versa
objectives: Pupils are able to convert percentage to decimals (example: 75% = 0.75) and vice versa using division/multiplication methods.
activities: Using a percentage-decimal conversion chart
'Quick Conversion' game – converting percentage to decimals
Solving daily problems: '20% discount, what is it in decimals?'
assessment: Oral assessment: 'How much is 40% in decimals?'

standards: 4.9.1 Solving daily problems involving addition and subtraction of money up to RM100,000
objectives: Pupils are able to solve daily situations such as buying items and finding the balance using addition/subtraction of money up to RM100,000.
activities: Drama: 'Buying a house for RM85,000, paid RM50,000, what is the balance?'
Using money problem story cards
Building mathematical sentences from real situations

standards: 4.9.2 Solving daily problems involving multiplication and division of money up to RM100,000
objectives: Pupils are able to solve daily situations such as the price of 5 units or unit price using multiplication/division of money up to RM100,000.
activities: Drama: 'One computer RM2,500, 4 computers = ?', 'RM10,000 for 5 books, how much per unit?'
Using money multiplication/division story cards
'Calculate Price' game in pairs
assessment: Worksheets for money multiplication/division problem solving

standards: 4.10.1 Performing addition operations involving time units (days, hours, minutes)
objectives: Pupils are able to solve addition mathematical sentences involving days, hours, and minutes (example: 2 days 3 hours + 1 day 5 hours).
activities: Using analog clocks and calendars to show time addition
'Add Time' game – adding time in groups
Solving daily problems: 'Started work Monday at 8:00, finished Friday at 4:30'

standards: 4.10.2 Performing subtraction operations involving time units (days, hours, minutes)
objectives: Pupils are able to solve subtraction mathematical sentences involving days, hours, and minutes (example: 3 days 2 hours – 1 day 5 hours).
activities: Using analog clocks and calendars to show time subtraction
'Subtract Time' game – subtracting time in pairs
Solving daily problems: 'Started project Monday at 9:00, finished Wednesday at 12:00'

standards: 4.11.1 Performing multiplication operations involving length (cm, m)
objectives: Pupils are able to solve mathematical sentences for multiplication involving length in cm and m (example: 2.5 m × 4).
activities: Measuring the length of an object and multiplying by a number
Using a number line to show length multiplication
Solving daily problems: 'A rope is 3.5 m long, 6 ropes = ?'
assessment: Observation of measurement and calculation accuracy
unit: Unit 11: Measurement (Length, Mass, Volume of Liquid - Multiplication & Division)

standards: 4.11.2 Performing division operations involving mass (g, kg) and volume of liquid (ml, liter)
objectives: Pupils are able to solve division mathematical sentences involving mass and volume of liquid in standard units (example: 5.6 kg ÷ 4).
activities: Weighing objects and dividing their mass into several parts
Pouring liquid and dividing its volume equally
Solving daily problems: '2.4 L of water divided into 6 bottles, how much in each bottle?'
assessment: Worksheets for mass and volume division operations
Oral Q&A: 'How much is each part?'
unit: Unit 11: Measurement (Length, Mass, Volume of Liquid - Multiplication & Division)

standards: 4.12.1 Calculating the area of squares and rectangles
objectives: Pupils are able to calculate the area of squares and rectangles using the formula (length × width) or the square grid method.
activities: Using square paper to count area
Building rectangles with base-ten blocks and counting area
Solving daily problems: 'Floor 6m x 4m, what is its area?'

standards: 4.12.2 Calculating the area of triangles, parallelograms, and trapeziums
objectives: Pupils are able to calculate the area of triangles, parallelograms, and trapeziums using formulas or the square grid method.
activities: Using grid paper to calculate triangle area
Building shapes with base-ten blocks and calculating area
Solving daily problems: 'Triangle with base 5m, height 3m'
assessment: Worksheets for calculating area of various shapes

standards: 4.13.1 Calculating the volume of a cuboid using the formula (length × width × height)
objectives: Pupils are able to calculate the volume of a cuboid using the formula or the base-ten blocks method.
activities: Using base-ten blocks to build a cuboid and calculate volume
Measuring dimensions of a cuboid and calculating volume
Solving daily problems: 'Box 5cm x 3cm x 2cm, what is its volume?'
kategori: Calculating the Volume of a Cuboid

standards: 4.13.2 Solving daily problems involving volume of cuboids
objectives: Pupils are able to solve daily situations such as filling water in a bathtub or a box using cuboid volume.
activities: Drama: 'Bathtub 2m x 1m x 0.5m, how many liters of water?'
Using volume problem story cards
'Calculate Volume' game in pairs
kategori: Calculating the Volume of a Cuboid

standards: 4.14.1 Measuring angles using a protractor
objectives: Pupils are able to measure angles (right, acute, obtuse) correctly using a protractor.
activities: Using a protractor to measure angles on paper
Finding angles in the environment and measuring with a protractor
'Measure Angle' game – measuring angles on cards
aids: Cards with various types of angles

standards: 4.14.2 Identifying and measuring right, acute, and obtuse angles
objectives: Pupils are able to identify and measure right (90°), acute (<90°), and obtuse (>90°) angles using a protractor.
activities: Drawing right, acute, and obtuse angles and measuring them
Finding angles in textbooks and measuring them
'Guess the Angle' game – teacher shows an angle, pupils guess the name and measure
assessment: Worksheets for labeling and measuring angles
Oral Q&A: 'What angle is this and how many degrees?'

standards: 4.15.1 Reading coordinates in the first quadrant (x, y)
objectives: Pupils are able to read and state coordinates of points on a Cartesian plane in the first quadrant (example: (3, 5)).
activities: Using a coordinate grid to mark points
'Find the Point' game – teacher says coordinates, pupils mark them
Drawing shapes using coordinates
kategori: Reading Coordinates in the First Quadrant

standards: 4.15.2 Marking points on a coordinate plane
objectives: Pupils are able to mark points on a coordinate plane based on ordered pairs (x, y) in the first quadrant.
activities: Marking points based on given coordinates
Building polygons by connecting coordinate points
'Draw the Shape' game – drawing shapes from coordinates
assessment: Worksheets for marking points and drawing shapes
kategori: Reading Coordinates in the First Quadrant

standards: 4.16.1 Identifying characteristics of regular polygons (all sides and angles equal)
objectives: Pupils are able to identify and state the characteristics of regular polygons (example: equilateral triangle, square).
activities: Finding regular polygons in the environment
Building regular polygons with popsicle sticks
'Guess the Polygon' game – teacher describes characteristics, pupils guess
assessment: Oral assessment: 'What are the characteristics of an equilateral triangle?'
unit: Unit 16: Polygons (Characteristics of Regular & Irregular Polygons)

standards: 4.16.2 Identifying characteristics of irregular polygons (sides and angles not equal)
objectives: Pupils are able to identify and state the characteristics of irregular polygons (example: rectangle, trapezium).
activities: Finding irregular polygons in the environment
Building irregular polygons with popsicle sticks
'Find the Difference' game – comparing regular vs irregular polygons
unit: Unit 16: Polygons (Characteristics of Regular & Irregular Polygons)

standards: 4.17.1 Identifying the center, radius, and diameter of a circle
objectives: Pupils are able to identify and state circle characteristics: center, radius, and diameter.
activities: Using paper circles to show center, radius, diameter
Drawing a circle and labeling its characteristics
'Guess the Characteristic' game – teacher points, pupils name the characteristic
assessment: Oral Q&A: 'Where is the radius? Where is the diameter?'

standards: 4.17.2 Measuring the radius and diameter of a circle
objectives: Pupils are able to measure the radius and diameter of a circle using a ruler or measuring tape.
activities: Measuring the radius and diameter of a real circle
Comparing radius and diameter (diameter = 2 × radius)
Solving daily problems: 'Wheel radius 25cm, diameter = ?'
assessment: Worksheets for measuring radius and diameter

standards: 4.18.1 Interpreting information from bar charts with scales
objectives: Pupils are able to read and interpret information from bar charts with scales (example: 1 unit = 5 people, how many people like blue?).
activities: Interpreting bar charts built by themselves
Q&A: 'Which is the most?', 'How many like red if 1 unit = 5?'
'Guess the Answer' game based on charts
unit: Unit 18: Data Management (Bar Charts - Scale, Mode, Mean, Median)
kategori: Interpreting Bar Charts and Basic Statistics

standards: 4.18.2 Calculating mode, mean, median, and range for a set of data
objectives: Pupils are able to calculate mode (most frequent value), mean (average), median (middle value), and range (difference between largest and smallest values) for a set of data.
activities: Collecting data on the number of books read by friends
Calculating mode, mean, median, range in groups
'Quick Statistics' game – calculating statistics within 1 minute
assessment: Worksheets for calculating mode, mean, median, range
aids: Pupil data (number of books, test marks)
unit: Unit 18: Data Management (Bar Charts - Scale, Mode, Mean, Median)
kategori: Interpreting Bar Charts and Basic Statistics
